member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.DragDrop.DragDropManager.AddDragInitializeHandler(System.Windows.DependencyObject,Telerik.Windows.DragDrop.DragInitializeEventHandler)
member.summary: Adds a DragInitialize event handler to a specified dependency object.
member.param: The dependency object (a UIElement or ContentElement) to which to add the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be added.
member.remarks: The DragInitialize event occurs when an object is about to be dragged. All needed information about the drag should be passed to the event arguments. Drag start can be stopped by setting Cancel=true.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.DragDrop.DragDropManager.AddDragInitializeHandler(System.Windows.DependencyObject,Telerik.Windows.DragDrop.DragInitializeEventHandler,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a DragInitialize event handler to a specified dependency object.
member.param: The dependency object (a UIElement or ContentElement) to which to add the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be added.

true to register the handler such that it is invoked even when the routed event is marked handled in its event data; false to register the handler with the default condition that it will not be invoked if the routed event is already marked handled. The default is false
member.remarks: The DragInitialize event occurs when an object is about to be dragged. All needed information about the drag should be passed to the event arguments. Drag start can be stopped by setting Cancel=true.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.DragDrop.DragDropManager.RemoveDragInitializeHandler(System.Windows.DependencyObject,Telerik.Windows.DragDrop.DragInitializeEventHandler)
member.summary: Removes a DragInitialize event handler from a specified dependency object.
member.param: The dependency object (a UIElement or ContentElement) from which to remove the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be removed.
member.remarks: The DragInitialize event occurs when an object is about to be dragged. All needed information about the drag should be passed to the event arguments. Drag start can be stopped by setting Cancel=true.

member.param: The dependency object (a UIElement or ContentElement) to which to add the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be added.
member.remarks: The DragEnter event occurs when an object is dragged into the element's bounds. This method adds a handler for the bubbling version of the DragEnter event. To add a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see AddPreviewDragEnterHandler.

true to register the handler such that it is invoked even when the routed event is marked handled in its event data; false to register the handler with the default condition that it will not be invoked if the routed event is already marked handled. The default is false
member.remarks: The DragEnter event occurs when an object is dragged into the element's bounds. This method adds a handler for the bubbling version of the DragEnter event. To add a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see AddPreviewDragEnterHandler.

A delegate that references the handler method to be removed.
member.remarks: The PreviewQueryContinueDrag event occurs during a drag-and-drop operation, and enables the drag source to determine whether the drag-and-drop operation should be canceled. This method removes a handler for the tunneling version of the PreviewQueryContinueDrag event. To remove a handler for the bubbling version of this event, see RemoveQueryContinueDragHandler.

member.summary: Reads a sequence of bytes from the current stream and advances the position within the stream by the number of bytes read.
member.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. This can be less than the number of bytes requested if that many bytes are not currently available, or zero (0) if the end of the stream has been reached.
member.param: An array of bytes. When this method returns, the buffer contains the specified byte array with the values between and ( + - 1) replaced by the bytes read from the current source.

The maximum number of bytes to be read from the current stream.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Arc class.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.Diameter
member.summary: Gets or sets the diameter of the generated arc graphic. It is recomended to use the same value for Width, Height and Diameter.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.StartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of the start point of the arc in degrees. The default is 10 which is near the right center. ~90 will be bottom ~180 left and ~270 top.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.EndAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of the end point of the arc in degrees. The default is 350 which is near the right center. ~90 will be bottom ~180 left and ~270 top.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.ArcThickness
member.summary: Gets or sets the thickness of the arc geometry. The value is the thickness in pixels in StretchMode="None" stretch mode. When the value increases the arc geometry expands toward the center of the arc. Do not set it to more than half the Diameter.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.MaximumProgress
member.summary: Gets or sets the aximum possible value of the Arc's Progress. It is designed to ease the Arc use in progress bars. Check the Progress property for more information.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.MinimumProgress
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum possible value of the Arc's Progress. It is designed to ease the Arc use in progress bars. Check the Progress property for more information.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.Progress
member.summary: Gets or sets the percentage of the arc to be drawn. Should be in range [MaximumProgress MinimumProgress]. The arc is drawn in clockwise direction from the StartAngle towards the EndAngle. Setting this property to MaximumProgress will draw all the arc. MaximumProgress * 0.5 + MinimumProgress * 0.5 - half of it. MinimumProgress - none of it. It is designed to ease the Arc use in progress bars.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Shapes.Arc.CapRadius
member.summary: Gets or sets the caps of the arc. 0 will use stright cut of a donut. Setting it to half the ArcThickness will draw geometry with circle ends of the arc. It is recomended to be in range from 0 to half the ArcThickness.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers
member.summary: This class presents a way to query the state of the various keyboard modifier keys. It also allows you to check the state of the shortcut key for the current platform.
member.remarks: The different platforms Silverlight runs on employ differring input conventions. Thus shortcuts for common actions such as Copy, Paste and Select All are activated using one key on Windows (Control), but using another on Mac OS X (Apple). Using this class should save you tedious platform checks. It is inadvisable, however, to use the IsShortcutKeyDown property before you've researched what the accepted shortcut for the relevant platform is. Even though this class addresses a Silverlight scenario, it will also work on WPF.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.PlatformID
member.summary: Gets or sets the PlatformID.
member.remarks: You only need to use this if you wish to mock this class.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.ModifierKeysFunc
member.summary: Gets or sets the Func that provides a ModifierKeys value.
member.remarks: You only need to use this if you wish to mock this class.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.Modifiers
member.summary: Gets the keyboard modifier keys.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.IsShortcutKeyDown
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the platform-specific shortcut meta key is pressed
member.remarks: For most systems (Windows + Linux) the shortcut key is Control. However, under Mac OS X the shortcut key is Apple (Command). Note that you still have to know if the relevant shortcut on Mac uses Command, because it can be entirely different.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.IsControlDown
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Control key is pressed.
member.value: true if the Control key is pressed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.IsAltDown
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Alt key is pressed.
member.value: true if the Alt key is pressed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.IsShiftDown
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Shift key is pressed.
member.value: true if the Shift key is pressed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.KeyboardModifiers.IsCommandDown
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Apple (Command) key is pressed.
member.value: true if the Apple (Command) key is pressed; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This is only appliccable on Silverlight under Mac OS X

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider
member.summary: Slider control lets the user select from a range of values by moving a slider. Slider is used to enable to user to gradually modify a value (range selection). Slider is an easy and natural interface for users, because it provides good visual feedback.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.IsSelectionRangeEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the RadSlider can displays a selection range. This is a dependency property.
member.remarks: The SelectionStart and SelectionEnd properties define a selection range and must be set for the selection range to appear when IsSelectionRangeEnabled is set to true.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.SelectionRange
member.summary: Gets the difference between SelectionStart and SelectionEnd.
member.value: The difference between SelectionStart and SelectionEnd.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.Selection
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether side ticks are enabled.
member.value: True if side ticks are enabled; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.SelectionEnd
member.summary: Gets or sets the largest value of a specified selection.
member.remarks: The value of the SelectionEnd property cannot be greater than the value of the Maximum property and cannot be less than the value of the Minimum property. The value of the SelectionEnd property must also be greater than or equal to the value of the SelectionStart property. If the value of the SelectionEnd property is greater than the value of the Maximum property or less than the value of the Minimum property, the value is set to the value of the Maximum or Minimum property respectively.

example.code: <telerik:RadSlider x:Name="radSlider1" Width="100" Orientation="Horizontal" Minimum="0" Maximum="10" TickPlacement="TopLeft" TickFrequency="1" IsSelectionRangeEnabled="True" SelectionEnd="8" SelectionStart="6"/>

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.SelectionStart
member.summary: Gets or sets the smallest value of a specified selection.
member.remarks: IsSelectionRangeEnabled must be True in order to use SelectionStart and SelectionEnd The value of the SelectionStart property cannot be less than the value of the Minimum property and cannot be greater than the value of the Maximum property. The value of the SelectionEnd property must also be greater than or equal to the value of the SelectionStart property. If SelectionStart is less than Minimum or greater than Maximum, SelectionStart is set to the value of Minimum or Maximum respectively.

example.code: <telerik:RadSlider x:Name="radSlider1" Width="100" Orientation="Horizontal" Minimum="0" Maximum="10" TickPlacement="TopLeft" TickFrequency="1" IsSelectionRangeEnabled="True" SelectionEnd="8" SelectionStart="6"/>

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.MinimumRangeSpan
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum value distance between SelectionStart and SelectionEnd.
member.remarks: The IsSelectionRangeEnabled property of RadSlider has to be set to True.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DoubleRangeBase.MaximumRangeSpan
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum value distance between SelectionStart and SelectionEnd.
member.remarks: The IsSelectionRangeEnabled property of RadSlider has to be set to True.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.StepAction
member.summary: This property determines how the slider will behave when in range mode. Setting this property to ChangeRange will move only the corresponding thumb when Large or Small step is performed. Setting the property to MoveRange will move the whole range when Large or Small change has been performed.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.Delay
member.summary: Gets or sets the Delay property of the Increase and Decrease handles.
member.remarks: Each click on any of the handles increases/decreases the value by the amount that is set to the SmallChange property.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.HandlesVisibility
member.summary: Gets or sets the Visibility property of the Increase and Decrease handles.
member.remarks: Each click on any of the handles increases/decreases the value by the amount that is set to the SmallChange property.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.RepeatInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the RepeatInterval property of the Increase and Decrease handles.
member.remarks: Each click on any of the handles increases/decreases the value by the amount that is set to the SmallChange property.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.IsDirectionReversed
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of increasing value. This is a dependency property.
member.remarks:
The value of this property determines the direction of increasing value of a RadRadSlider.
For example, when you move the thumb control up on a vertical RadSlider when the IsDirectionReversed property is set to false, the Value of the RadSlider increases. If the value of the IsDirectionReversed property is changed to true, the Value of the RadSlider decreases as the thumb moves up.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.IsMoveToPointEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the thumb of a RadSlider moves immediately to the location of the mouse click that occurs while the mouse pointer pauses on the RadSlider track. This is a dependency property.
member.remarks: When this property is set to false and a mouse click occurs along the RadSlider away from the thumb, the thumb moves in the direction of the mouse click. Instead of moving immediately to the mouse click location, the thumb moves a distance that is defined by the RepeatInterval property for each mouse click. The effect of multiple mouse clicks can be emulated by pressing and holding the left mouse button until the thumb is repositioned to the desired location.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadSlider.IsSnapToTickEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the RadSlider automatically moves the thumb to the closest tick mark. This is a dependency property.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes
member.summary: Contains a list of possible chunk type identifier.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.Header
member.summary: The first chunk in a png file. Can only exists once. Contains common information like the width and the height of the image or the used compression method.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.Palette
member.summary: The PLTE chunk contains from 1 to 256 palette entries, each a three byte series in the RGB format.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.Data
member.summary: The IDAT chunk contains the actual image data. The image can contains more than one chunk of this type. All chunks together are the whole image.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.End
member.summary: This chunk must appear last. It marks the end of the PNG datastream. The chunk's data field is empty.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.PaletteAlpha
member.summary: This chunk specifies that the image uses simple transparency: either alpha values associated with palette entries (for indexed-color images) or a single transparent color (for grayscale and truecolor images).

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.Text
member.summary: Textual information that the encoder wishes to record with the image can be stored in tEXt chunks. Each tEXt chunk contains a keyword and a text string.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngChunkTypes.Gamma
member.summary: Thes chunk specifies the relationship between the image samples and the desired display output intensity.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader
member.summary: Represents the png header chunk.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.Width
member.summary: The dimension in x-direction of the image in pixels.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.Height
member.summary: The dimension in y-direction of the image in pixels.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.BitDepth
member.summary: Bit depth is a single-byte integer giving the number of bits per sample or per palette index (not per pixel). Valid values are 1, 2, 4, 8, and 16, although not all values are allowed for all color types.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.ColorType
member.summary: Color type is a integer that describes the interpretation of the image data. Color type codes represent sums of the following values: 1 (palette used), 2 (color used), and 4 (alpha channel used).

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.CompressionMethod
member.summary: Indicates the method used to compress the image data. At present, only compression method 0 (deflate/inflate compression with a sliding window of at most 32768 bytes) is defined.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.FilterMethod
member.summary: Indicates the preprocessing method applied to the image data before compression. At present, only filter method 0 (adaptive filtering with five basic filter types) is defined.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Media.Imaging.PngBitmapEncoder.PngHeader.InterlaceMethod
member.summary: Indicates the transmission order of the image data. Two values are currently defined: 0 (no interlace) or 1 (Adam7 interlace).

<LinearGradientBrush EndPoint="0 1"> <LinearGradientBrush.RelativeTransform> <TranslateTransform Y="0" /> </LinearGradientBrush.RelativeTransform> <GradientStop Offset="0" Color="Transparent" /> <GradientStop Offset="0" Color="Black" /> <GradientStop Offset="1" Color="Black" /> <GradientStop Offset="1" Color="Transparent" /> </LinearGradientBrush>
member.param: The object to set the mask for.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.DataTemplateSelector
member.summary: Provides a way to choose a DataTemplate based on the data object and the data-bound element.

remarks.para: Typically, you create a DataTemplateSelector when you have more than one DataTemplate for the same type of objects and you want to supply your own logic to choose a DataTemplate to apply based on the properties of each data object.

To create a template selector, create a class that inherits from DataTemplateSelector and override the SelectTemplate method. Once your class is defined you can assign an instance of the class to the template selector property of your element.

member.param: The data object for which to select the template.
The data-bound object.

member.summary: Registers a class handler for a particular routed event.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.EventManager.RegisterClassHandler(System.Type,Telerik.Windows.RoutedEvent,System.Delegate,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Registers a class handler for a particular routed event, with the option to handle events where event data is already marked handled.
member.param: The type of the class that is declaring class handling.
The routed event identifier of the event to handle.
A reference to the class handler implementation.
True to invoke this class handler even if arguments of the routed event have been marked as handled; false to retain the default behavior of not invoking the handler on any marked-handled event.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.EventManager.RegisterRoutedEvent(System.String,Telerik.Windows.RoutingStrategy,System.Type,System.Type)
member.summary: Registers a new routed event with the Silverlight event system.
member.param: The name of the routed event. The name must be unique within the owner type and cannot be null (Nothing in Visual Basic) or an empty string.
The routing strategy of the event as a value of the enumeration.
The type of the event handler. This must be a delegate type and cannot be null (Nothing in Visual Basic).
The owner class type of the routed event. This cannot be null (Nothing in Visual Basic).
member.returns: The identifier for the newly registered routed event. This identifier object can now be stored as a static field in a class and then used as a parameter for methods that attach handlers to the event. The routed event identifier is also used for other event system APIs.

member.summary: Indicates the routing strategy of a routed event.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.RoutingStrategy.Tunnel
member.summary: The routed event uses a tunneling strategy, where the event instance routes downwards through the tree, from root to source element.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.RoutingStrategy.Bubble
member.summary: The routed event uses a bubbling strategy, where the event instance routes upwards through the tree, from event source to root.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.RoutingStrategy.Direct
member.summary: The routed event does not route through an element tree, but does support other routed event capabilities such as class handling, EventTrigger or EventSetter.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode
member.summary: Describes the placement of where a Popup control appears on the screen.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.Absolute
member.summary: A position of the Popup control relative to the upper-left corner of the screen and at an offset that is defined by the HorizontalOffset and VerticalOffset property values. If the screen edge obscures the Popup, the control then repositions itself to align with the edge.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.Bottom
member.summary: A position of the Popup control where the control aligns its upper edge with the lower edge of the PlacementTarget and aligns its left edge with the left edge of the PlacementTarget. If the lower screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself so that its lower edge aligns with the upper edge of the PlacementTarget. If the upper screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control then repositions itself so that its upper edge aligns with the upper screen-edge.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.Center
member.summary: A position of the Popup control where it is centered over the PlacementTarget. If a screen edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself to align with the screen edge.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.Right
member.summary: A position of the Popup control that aligns its left edge with the right edge of the PlacementTarget and aligns its upper edge with the upper edge of the PlacementTarget. If the right screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself so that its left edge aligns with the left edge of the PlacementTarget. If the left screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself so that its left edge aligns with the left screen-edge. If the upper or lower screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control then repositions itself to align with the obscuring screen edge.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.MousePoint
member.summary: A postion of the Popup control that aligns its upper edge with the lower edge of the bounding box of the mouse and aligns its left edge with the left edge of the bounding box of the mouse. If the lower screen-edge obscures the Popup, it repositions itself to align with the upper edge of the bounding box of the mouse. If the upper screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself to align with the upper screen-edge.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.Left
member.summary: A Popup control that aligns its right edge with the left edge of the PlacementTarget and aligns its upper edge with the upper edge of the PlacementTarget. If the left screen-edge obscures the Popup, the Popup repositions itself so that its left edge aligns with the right edge of the PlacementTarget. If the right screen-edge obscures the Popup, the right edge of the control aligns with the right screen-edge. If the upper or lower screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself to align with the obscuring screen edge.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.PlacementMode.Top
member.summary: A position of the Popup control that aligns its lower edge with the upper edge of the PlacementTarget and aligns its left edge with the left edge of the PlacementTarget. If the upper screen-edge obscures the Popup, the control repositions itself so that its upper edge aligns with the lower edge of the PlacementTarget. If the lower screen-edge obscures the Popup, the lower edge of the control aligns with the lower screen-edge. If the left or right screen-edge obscures the Popup, it then repositions itself to align with the obscuring screen.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.RadProgressBar
member.summary: The RadProgressBar control can be used to to indicate the progress of an operation. It gives to an end-user visual feedback about an operation he is waiting for to complete.
member.remarks: The RadProgressBar control should be used as a visual indication of the progress of an operation. The developer is responsible for programatically updating the value of the RadProgressBar, while the control takes care of the visual representation of its value.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter
member.summary: Represents a presenter that changes its size smoothly when its content is resized.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter.DurationProperty
member.summary: Identifies the Duration property.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter.EasingProperty
member.summary: Identifies the Easing property.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the FluildResizePresenter.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter.MeasureOverride(System.Windows.Size)
member.summary: Provides the behavior for the Measure pass of Silverlight layout. Classes can override this method to define their own Measure pass behavior.
member.param: The available size that this object can give to child objects. Infinity (System.Double.PositiveInfinity) can be specified as a value to indicate that the object will size to whatever content is available.
member.returns: The size that this object determines it needs during layout, based on its calculations of the allocated sizes for child objects; or based on other considerations, such as a fixed container size.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter.Duration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of the animation. This is a DependencyProperty.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.FluidResizePresenter.Easing
member.summary: Gets or sets a value describing the easing function to be used for the animation.

member.name: T:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.Transition
member.summary: Abstract class that represents a transition between two visual.

member.name: F:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.Transition.ProgressProperty
member.summary: Identifies the Progress property. When its value is 0.0 the effect shows the initial state of the transition, when 1.0 - the final state.

member.name: M:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionControl.Transition.OnProgressChanged(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: This method is called when the progress of the transition is changed. When overriden it should take care of moving the transition.

member.summary: A map that indicates the order of the progress of the pixels. White areas of the map transition before

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.MappedLightTransition.WaveLength
member.summary: Determines how fast will happen the transition of each separate pixel. Default is 1. 0 will swap the old colors with the new without transition. High values will make the transition ignore the ProgressMap. Best used with values in range 0.1 to 1.

member.summary: Provides information about the planes with the old and new content in a PerspectiveTransition.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.PerspectiveTransitionState.CameraDistance
member.summary: The distance from the camera to the display. Values less then 1 may render artifacts. Values near 2 render best perspective feeling. Large value will result in almost stereometrical projection.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.PerspectiveTransitionState.NewPlaneTransform
member.summary: Provides simplified coordinates and rotation of the plane with image of the new content.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.PerspectiveTransitionState.OldPlaneTransform
member.summary: Provides simplified coordinates and rotation of the plane with image of the old content.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.PerspectiveTransitionState.NewPlaneColorMultiply
member.summary: The color of the new image will be multiplied by this value. Default is white which does not affect the image. Transparent renders invisible. Any other color will filter the image.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.PerspectiveTransitionState.OldPlaneColorMultiply
member.summary: The color of the old image will be multiplied by this value. Default is white which does not affect the image. Transparent renders invisible. Any other color will filter the image.

member.name: P:Telerik.Windows.Controls.TransitionEffects.PerspectiveTransitionState.IsNewInFrontOfOld

member.name: T:System.Windows.CanExecuteChangedEventManager
member.summary: Provides a WeakEventManager implementation so that you can use the "weak event listener" pattern to attach listeners for the ICommand.CanExecuteChanged events.

member.name: T:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1
member.summary: Provides a base class for the event manager that is used in the weak event pattern. The manager adds and removes listeners for events (or callbacks) that also use the pattern.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes base class values when it is used as the initializer by the constructor of a derived class.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.CheckForNull(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Helper method that throw ArgumentNullException if given source is null.
member.param: The element that is check for null.
The name that should be passed to ArgumentNullException constructor.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.StartListening(System.Object)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, starts listening for the event being managed. After the StartListening method is first called, the manager should be in the state of calling DeliverEvent or DeliverEventToList whenever the relevant event from the provided source is handled.
member.param: The source to begin listening on.
member.remarks: Notes to Inheritors StartListening overrides should add a handler to the provided source. The handler is declared by the manager itself. The class handler should not be public, and it should only be called in response to the event being managed. The class handler should call the DeliverEvent method or the DeliverEventToList method appropriately.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.StopListening(System.Object)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, stops listening on the provided source for the event being managed.
member.param: The source to stop listening on.
member.remarks: Notes to Inheritors StopListening implementations should remove the class handler as added by the StartListening method. Removing a listener should not clear the listener list. Instead, it should only disconnect the class handler (perhaps temporarily).

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ProtectedAddListener(`0,System.Windows.IWeakEventListener)
member.summary: Adds the provided listener to the provided source for the event being managed.
member.param: The source to attach listeners to.
The listening class (which must implement IWeakEventListener).
member.remarks: Call this method within your manager class AddListener methods on WeakEventManager implementations. AddListener is the suggested name for the static method you define on your manager class to enable other classes to add a listener for your weak event pattern. AddListener should take two parameters: the source where the listener is attached, and the listener instance. For your AddListener implementation, call the ProtectedAddListener method on the current manager and pass the same two parameters. If the list of listeners was previously empty, ProtectedAddListener calls the StartListening method internally, which will call your specific StartListening override through polymorphism. ProtectedAddListener adds listeners to a single internal WeakEventManager.ListenerList per source. If your manager implementation maintains more than one list of listeners for each event-source combination, do not use ProtectedAddListener. Instead, your implementation should create its own WeakEventManager.ListenerList instances, AddListener should add listeners to the appropriate list, and events should be delivered to the appropriate listener list by calling the DeliverEventToList event instead of the DeliverEvent method.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ProtectedRemoveListener(`0,System.Windows.IWeakEventListener)
member.summary: Removes a previously added listener from the provided source.
member.param: The source to remove listeners from.
The listening class (which must implement IWeakEventListener).
member.remarks: Call this method within your manager class RemoveListener methods on WeakEventManager implementations. RemoveListener is the suggested name for the static method you define on your manager class to enable other classes to remove a listener for your weak event pattern. RemoveListener should take two parameters: the source where the listener is removed, and the listener class. For your RemoveListener implementation, call the ProtectedRemoveListener method on the current manager and pass the same two parameters. If a call to ProtectedRemoveListener removes the last listener in the list, ProtectedRemoveListener calls the StopListening method internally, which will call your specific StopListening override through polymorphism. ProtectedRemoveListener removes listeners from a single internal WeakEventManager.ListenerList per source. If your manager implementation maintains more than one list of listeners for each event-source combination, do not use ProtectedRemoveListener. Instead, your implementation should create its own WeakEventManager.ListenerList instances, RemoveListener should remove listeners from the appropriate list, and events should be delivered to the appropriate listener list by calling the DeliverEventToList method instead of the DeliverEvent method.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.DeliverEventToList(System.Object,System.EventArgs,System.Windows.WeakEventManager{`0}.ListenerList)
member.summary: Delivers the event being managed to each listener in the provided list.
member.param: The object on which the event is being handled.
An EventArgs that contains the event data.
The provided ListenerList.
member.remarks: This method is necessary if your manager implementation maintains separate listeners lists based on information that is captured in the event data. If you use this advanced technique, you must create and maintain the separate lists as part of your manager implementation, and you must provide a way to add listeners to a specific list. Your handler implementation that listens to the raw event must act upon the condition that you use to differentiate the lists, and deliver the event only to the appropriate list or lists.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.DeliverEvent(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Delivers the event being managed to each listener.
member.param: The object on which the event is being handled.
An EventArgs that contains the event data for the event to deliver.
member.remarks: Call the DeliverEvent method from within the event handlers that are added or removed by the StartListening and StopListening implementations of subclasses. If you call the ProtectedAddListener method in your AddListener implementation of your class, the list of listeners receiving the event is kept in an underlying collection. (AddListener is not part of an interface or class contract. AddListener is the suggested name for the method of your manager class that calls ProtectedAddListener and adds weak event pattern listeners for the event.) ProtectedAddListener adds listeners to a single list. If your manager implementation maintains more than one list of listeners per event, do not use DeliverEvent or ProtectedAddListener. Instead, your implementation should create its own WeakEventManager.ListenerList instances, AddListener should add listeners to the appropriate list, and events should be delivered to the appropriate listener list by calling DeliverEventToList.

member.name: T:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList
member.summary: Provides a built-in collection list for storing listeners for a WeakEventManager.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the WeakEventManager.ListenerList class.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the WeakEventManager.ListenerList class with the specified initial capacity.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.Add(System.Windows.IWeakEventListener)
member.summary: Adds a listener item to the WeakEventManager.ListenerList.
member.param: The listener element to add to the WeakEventManager.ListenerList.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.BeginUse
member.summary: Declares the list to be in use. This prevents direct changes to the list during iterations of the list items.
member.returns: true if the list was already declared to be in use; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: A WeakEventManager implementation should call BeginUse before iterating through the list to deliver an event to the listeners, and should call EndUse when it is done. This prevents another caller from modifying the list while the iteration for purposes of event delivery is in progress. If the list is modified during this time, then the list is cloned. If the list is cloned, then PrepareForWriting returns true, which means that you have missed a recent listener change in the last delivery.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.Clone
member.summary: Creates a modifiable clone of this WeakEventManager.ListenerList.
member.returns: A modifiable clone of the current object.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.EndUse
member.summary: Unlocks the locked state initiated by BeginUse.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting(System.Windows.WeakEventManager{`0}.ListenerList@)
member.summary: Checks to see whether the provided list is in use, and if so, sets the list reference parameter to a copy of that list rather than the original.
member.param: The list to check for use state and potentially copy.
member.returns: true if the provided list was in use at the time of call and therefore the list parameter reference was reset to be a copy. false if the provided list was not in use, in which case the list parameter reference remains unaltered.

member.name: M:System.Windows.WeakEventManager`1.ListenerList.Purge
member.summary: Removes all entries from the list where the underlying reference target is a null reference.
member.returns: Returns true if any entries were purged; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Removes the first occurrence of a listener item from the WeakEventManager.ListenerList.
member.param: The item to remove.
